title: Deepfix: Statistical Post-editing of Statistical Machine Translation Using Deep Syntactic Analysis

author: Rudolf Rosa, Institute of Formal and Applied Linguistics (ÚFAL), Charles University Prague

segmentation: So I will present to work with my colleagues on the Deepak system which performs statistical post editing of statistical machine translation using deep syntactic analysis.
So far.
Work.
Let's start with the motivation.
So imagine that we have source text in English.
EU criticizes not only the Greek government and we want to translate it to check.
So this is the result collected from Google Translate today.

It is then that Scarlotta, which unfortunately is not the correct translation, because the actually the meaning is reversed because just cover is in the nominative case, which in check marks the subject.
So actually it means that it's the re government who criticizes the European Union.
So what our system does is that it fix this kind of error.
So we try to find this kind of error to put the argument into the correct morphological case.
In this situation it's the accusative case, which would mark the object and the meaning would be the correct one.
How do we do?
Edit So I will first define the problem properly using the notion of balancing.
Then I will talk about the system itself, which has two steps.
The first step is the deep step where we perform deep dependency passing of the sentence to find the errors and the second step to fixing step is where we actually do fix the errors.
Using a statistical model of balancing and I will evaluate our approach as well.
So in the example sentence we saw that the problem was in the subject object dichotomy.
Uh, the problem is that in checking in English, subject and object are mark in very different ways.
In English it's pretty simple because the subject is the constituent of the web that's on the left and the object is on the right.
But in Czech it's more tricky because we mark the subject and object by its morphological case for the subject.
It's not so hard.
It's typically the nominative case for the object.
It can be various cases depending on the verb.
In this example we need the accusative case for the verb to criticize.

And on the other hand, word order is not really important, because check has a relatively free word order, so you can use many permutations of the word and the meaning is still preserved if the cases are correct.
So again, I said that we will use the notion of valenci.
So if you don't know anything balanced, so about balances, so you can just take it as the idea that verb requires some arguments in some cases for check or in some positions for English.
This will be enough for the talk.
So in this case we are interested in the valancy of the verb to criticize or correct this event in check, and we can define its valence iframe as the arguments it requires.
Now, for English, the position of the arguments is important, while in check it's the cases of the arguments.
So still in check it's a subject and an object, but it's marked by the case.
And so.
For our approach, we just decompose the whole frame into the head argument pairs.
So it's it's.
Yeah, the head is the verb.
The argument in this case is the government.
Now let's now let's get to the system itself.
We perform complex analyzes of the both the English sentence and then the translation that we get from the SMT system.
We use mostly already existing tools for the analysis, so we do taking lemmatization, we do word alignment.
We do dependency parsing where we had to adapt the parser a bit.
Is the MST parser, but it's adapted for the SMT outputs which are often erroneous, so the parser cannot rely on it so much.
And so then we construct deep structure.
It's called detector grammatical structure.
If you're familiar with that.
If not, it doesn't matter.
And.
I'll show what it could look like, so for the sentence you criticize the Greek government.
So we take the lemmas so, like criticize, you can see that functional words are removed like that because we just don't need it.
And so you can see that the verb criticises two arguments, EU and government, and then the government has an attribute Greek.
Now we use the word alignment because we need to know that actually you corresponds to EU in check and government corresponds tevada.
Then we have a lot of labels.
I only show two or three types of labels, so the part of speech like the verb noun or objective and then again in English we have the subject or big object.
KOMA, which is easy to determine by the position.
Whereas in check I have there the morphological case.
And in this case, it's the incorrect one, so both of the words are actually in nominative.
Well, for you, you cannot really tell the case because it's a shortcut that doesn't inflect, so it.
It's what we will try to correct anyway.
So we are now interested in this head argument pair.
So the head is the verb criticize.
The argument is the noun government.
And yeah, we'll try to fix.
There are so.
We proceed to the second phase to fixing itself.
For this we use violence models.
It's probably the simplest way to create statistical variance models, so we use large scale parallel data and we estimate the probabilities of the case of the argument.
So in this case of the word voda and we condition it on the lemma of the head.
So in this case it's correct is about and the.
Yeah, the marker of the English argument, so that's the object.
So the question is, if we have the verb kritis around and an argument which should correspond to an object, which case should we give to such argument?
We also have a more fine grained model which also takes into account the lemma of the check argument.
Um?
Yeah, but I will just stick to the first one, which is simpler.
Um?
So in this, in this exact case we are interested in these two probabilities.
Of course there might be other cases, but probably sum to one, so we are actually interested only in the most probable case.
Well, in this case it's obvious that nominative doesn't look like the correct one.
It has only 3% estimated probability, whereas the accusative has about 80%.
Still, we need to formalize that a little.
So what we do to decide whether we should change the case to the more probable one is that we use threshold for this situation.
So if the most probable case has a probability of at least 55%, we do.
Change the case of the argument.
The threshold is somehow manually estimated.
Nothing special, so if we look at the sentence itself, so this is again the incorrect sentence where the argument is in nominative case.
So using develops a model.
We can change the case of the argument itself toward government Lada to the accusative.
And because in check we need an agreement of the objective, and now we then also enforce the agreement.
So we also changed the case of the objective Greek.
Can we get a correct sentence?
So.
That's the system we evaluated on top of the Moses translation system.
Um?
On three datasets.
You can see that the improvement is very small.
But it's actually it's consistently positive, so we still believe that it's an indication that our approach works, although it does not bring any massive improvement of translation quality.
This is the standard blue metric, which is like the standard for machine trans.
Nation we also tried Nest which agrees with blue and we tried.
At.
So.
Position independent word error rate.
Which also agrees with the other two metrics.
So it's a small but consistent improvement.
Well, we also performed manual evaluation because, well, the automatic didn't tell us much.
So it was.
We took about 500 sentences that were changed by defect system and we had a group of annotators to decide whether the change performed by the fix did actually improved translation.
So this is the green portion, or whether it actually worse than the translation, which can happen if actually the case was correct and we just changed it.
If even though we shouldn't have.
Or it might happen that the change is indefinite, which means that probably the case wasn't correct.
But it isn't correct.
After the correction either.

So it's just impossible to evaluate, and we can see that in more than 1/2 of cases deep fixed us actually improve the quality of the translation, although it's probably only minor correction, it might influence the meaning, because it might.
Example sentence, it might actually fix the subject an object marking.
And yes, still about 1/4 of the cases were.
Yeah, worsening's.
So to conclude.
We designed a system to fix errors in valenci in the outputs of statistical machine translation an we find the currency pairs using deep syntactic analyzes and we try to fix the errors.
We try to find the best morphological case for the argument using statistical balance model so.
So we actually bring together the statistics and then some expert knowledge which is put into the deep analysis.
Um?
We performed an evaluation which showed that we are able to obtain a slight improvement of translation quality which is.
Which is indicated by the automatic evolution and confirmed by the manual evaluation.
Well, the future work.
I think you could guess.
One thing we didn't try to use existing valancy lexicons which could either replace the models that we use or compliment to models that we use.
So this is definitely something that we would like to look into.
Then, as I said, the modeling that we use is rather simple, so we will try to one thing we would try to do is to combine more models.
And then to do some like real machine learning.
So now we have just some thresholds that we found, and it's most probably over fitted to the development data.
And another thing we would like to adapt tools a little because when we have the task of analyzing machine translation outputs there, it's often erroneous and the tools can get really confused.
So we would like we already adapted parser in away and we would like to adopt A Tiger as well.
So of course it would be nice to extend it to other language pairs, especially in translation to other morphologically rich.
Languages.
OK, thank you.
Have you compared this approach with the think nickel 2009 stuff that Pascale Fung and I?
Did to post statically post edit SMT output using Prop bank style semantic analysis.
I don't think I have come across this work, so I will definitely try to look into it, so I'm sorry.
Yeah, I found some similar work, but I haven't found any post editing using any any kind of structures like trees, so this is something that I would definitely like to see.
Hi, thank you for the talk.
What's the error density of these sort of like incorrect case assignments?
How?
How often does it occur in your data?
Yeah, I don't think I have the error analyzes at hand, but it's it's quite common because the phrase systems have problems with such situation.
Usually when there is a gap in the phrase or when it's too uncommon words.
So it's quite quite common.
I would estimate that maybe 2030% of sentences contain such an error.
But it's very rough estimation.
Anymore questions.
I have one.
Sort of in line with that.
So based on the density of the number of errors that in which this is found and also seen the amount of improvement that it does, how costly is deep fix for?
For such, I want to say slight improvement.
I mean obviously on the sentences that are having troubles.
It's more than half of them are adjusted, but yeah.
So well, the good thing is that it's statistical, so you just have to have a lot of data.
But of course you still need way to analyze the sentences.
Yeah, I don't think that you necessarily need this kind of formalism that we use.
You just basically need to be able to identify the head argument pairs.
So I guess there are tools for a lot of languages which can do that, and that of course you have to have some representation of what you are trying to find.
So in this case it's the set of seven cases for check.
Yeah, so I would imagine that once it already exists for one language pair, it shouldn't be much trouble to adapt it to another language pair because there is very little like hand work.
Anymore 'cause I actually have another one.
If you guys don't mind.
So you mainly did it from English to Czech right?
Which is morphologically rich.
Is there the same amount of advantage going in the other direction?
Is there any is the same amount of error rate and is there a same advantage going in the other direction for morphologically rich tonight?
Well.
Yeah, I can't think of much cases where this would help for English.
Well, actually we do a bit more than I showed.
We also model the prepositions that go together with the words.
So this is definitely something that you can use for like many languages.
So yeah, I guess that the preposition prepositions could be used even for translation into English.
We haven't tried it, but I think it would be possible.
I would have been my other question.
OK, I guess we could thank the speaker again stickers.
